Note: You can add additional Hit Locations as desired. This is only for a Hit Location selection, it does not apply any modifiers to the die roll - for that you need to manually enter that value as a modifier when clicking the Macro button.
ranged-damage-notes-tooltip:
Any standard notes entered here will appear in the Roll Template in chat.
Hint: Enter inline rolls for additional results.
Example: Does an additional [[1d6]] fire damage.
thrown-tooltip:
This is the ability to throw any small, relatively smooth object
that fits in the palm of your hand.
See the Throwing skill (B226). Also see Throwing rules (B355).
thrown-strength-tooltip:
Baseado no valor da ST de Golpe.
NOTA: As futuras versões dessa ficha, irão adicionar capacidade de escolher a fonte da ST ou digitar a ST.
thrown-strength-modifier-tooltip:
Bônus de ST quando estiver calculando a distância de arremesso.
Arremesso ou Arte do Arremesso: Se tiver NH igual a DX nesta perícia, adicione um bônus de +1 à ST.
Arremesso ou Arte do Arremesso: Se o NH for maior ou igual a DX+1 nesta perícia, adicione um bônus de +2 à ST.
thrown-super-tooltip:
Nível do Super Arremesso.
Cada Nível de Super Arremesso dobra o alcance.
Para cada Nível de Super Arremesso adicione um bônus de +2 por dado de dano.
Veja Supers, pág. 30.
thrown-damage-tooltip: Dano final baseado no valor da ST de Golpe, Super Arremesso e o Bônus ou Penalidade por dado de dano.
thrown-damage-modifier-tooltip:
Bônus ou Penalidade por dado de dano.
Arte do Arremesso: Se tiver NH igual a DX nesta perícia, adicione um bônus de +1 por dado de dano.
Arte do Arremesso: Se o NH for maior ou igual a DX+1 nesta perícia, adicione um bônus de +2 por dado de dano.
thrown-link-to-note: Throwing uses DX-3 to hit a specific target, DX to lob something into a general area, or you can use the Throwing skill (B226). Also see Throwing rules (B355).
thrown-reason-for-modifiers-label: Reason for all modifiers (ST, Damage, Skill)
gravity-thrown-tooltip: Gravidade, afeta a distância de arremesso. Veja B351.
firing-up-down-range-tooltip: Distância entre você e o alvo. Veja B372-373.
firing-up-down-speed-tooltip:
Velocidade
(3 km/h = 1 m/s).
Ignore a velocidade se o alvo estiver se movendo numa velocidade padrão para um humano (até Deslocamento 10).
Veja B372-373.
effective-speed-range-tooltip: Velocidade/Distância efetiva baseada na Distância, Velocidade e Elevação.
apply-firing-tooltip: Aplique esses Modificadores de Ataques à Distância na caixa de diálogo Modificadores de Teste.
close-range-shotgun-label: Ferramenta de Dano para Espingarda em Curta Distância
close-range-shotgun-label-tooltip:
Used for extremely close combat at a range of 10% of the ½D Range or less.
See Shotguns and Multiple Projectiles for more details.
shotgun-half-damage-tooltip:
1/2 Distância
Insira o Alcance Relativo à Metade do Dano (1/2D) da espingarda.
shotgun-notes-description: Insira as estatísticas da espingarda, certifique-se de usar o Alcance Relativo à Metade do Dano. A ferramenta calculará o quão próxima você precisa estar com a espingarda, o CdT, o dano em curta distância e o multiplicador RD. Veja B409.
slam-attack-notes: Foe may block, dodge, or parry (but your body counts as a heavy weapon; see Parrying Heavy Weapons B376). If your foe dodges, you must move at least two yards past him if you have enough movement. If you would hit someone else, see Hitting the Wrong Target (B389).
slam-damage-notes:
Damage Contest: You and your foe each inflict dice of crushing damage on the other. If your damage roll equals or exceeds that of your foe, they must make a DX roll or fall down.

You knock him down automatically if you roll twice their damage or more. If they rolls twice your damage or more, though, you fall down instead!
slam-attack-tooltip: Slam requires an Attack, All-out Attack, or Move and Attack maneuver. Your foe may block, dodge, or parry (but your body counts as a heavy weapon; see Parrying Heavy Weapons B376). If your foe dodges, you must move at least two yards past them if you have enough movement. If you would hit someone else, see Hitting the Wrong Target (B389). You can use All-Out Attack (Strong), +2 to Damage (B365), to increase your damage! (B371)
slam-velocity-tooltip:
Relative velocity is Yards/Meters/Hexes Per Second (1 Yard Per Second is about 2 MPH B430) and is applied to both objects!
If collision, use relative velocity.
Head-on collision = Add velocity of both objects
Rearend collision = Faster object - slower object
Side collision = Speed of object causing collision.
B432
slam-link-to-note: Slam uses either DX, Brawling, or Sumo Wrestling. Note that the -4 to hit and effective skill cap of 9 for a Move and Attack do not apply to slams. (B371)
slam-flying-tackle-tooltip: +4 to hit and +1 to Reach, may use Jumping Skill for attack. You end up lying prone in the same hex as target. B372
slam-pounce-tooltip: If you have four or more legs, you may pounce. +4 to hit and +1 to Reach, may use Jumping Skill for attack. After you attack, make a DX, Acrobatics, or Jumping roll. On a success, you stay on your feet! If a mount tries this, the rider must roll vs. Riding-4 or fall off! B372
slam-shield-rush-tooltip: Roll against Shield skill to hit, and add your shield's Defense Bonus to your damage roll. Your shield takes damage instead of you. B372
slam-overrun-tooltip: If your SM is 2 or more than the target, apply overrun damage. This inflicts additional crushing damage based on ST = Your HP/2. B432
yards-fallen-tooltip:
Controlled Fall Acrobatics skill to land properly can reduce fall by 5 yards.
If falling into water, you can attempt an Acrobatic skill or proper dive/ditch.
Dive/Ditch Swimming or Vehicle skill minus the speed penalty from Size and Speed/Range Table B550.
On a successful roll, you take no damage. B431
atmosphere-tooltip: Atmosphere is used to determine the Terminal Velocity Multiplier. (B431)
falling-velocity-tooltip:
Relative velocity is Yards/Meters/Hexes Per Second (1 Yard Per Second is about 2 MPH B430) and is applied to both objects!
See Velocity Table and Formula on B430.
If collision, use relative velocity.
Head-on collision = Add velocity of both objects
Rearend collision = Faster object - slower object
Side collision = Speed of object causing collision.
B432
terminal-velocity-tooltip:
Terminal Velocity Multiplier
Terminal Velocity On Earth, human-shaped 60 (spread-eagle) to 100 (dive) yards/second. Dense objects can be up to 200 yards/second or more. (B431).
Use the multiplier below to determine the new terminal velocity.
falling-hit-points-tooltip:
Hit Points of falling object or object initiating
collision.
NOTE: If collision and if the target object is moving
it will inflict its own damage to object that initiated
the collision.
See B430
hard-object-tooltip: If hitting a hard object (clay, concrete, soil, sand, etc.), check the box to double the effective Hit Points of the falling object or the object that caused the collision. B431
falling-damage-type-tooltip: Normal objects are crushing. If bullet-shaped, sharp, or spiked select appropriate damage type, but damage is halved. B430
demolition-select-tooltip: Selecione um tipo de explosivo a ser usado. Isso preencherá os campos Tipo e REF.
demolition-type-tooltip:
Tipo
Consulte FER na Tabela de Forca Explosiva Relativa, B415.
demolition-pounds-tooltip: Weight in required by its REF.
demolition-base-damage-tooltip: Dano básico. Nas regras conforme escritas é 6d6.
damage-multiplier-tooltip:
Multiplicador de Dano:
Digite o número para multiplicar por 6d6.
Uma explosão que causa 6dxn pontos de danos necessita de (n x n)/8 quilogramas de TNT.
NOTA: Qualquer um pego em uma explosão pode tentar se jogar ao chão. Veja Esquiva e Queda, B377.
radius-collateral-damage-tooltip:
Raio de dano colateral
Por exemplo, numa explosão de 6dx2 pontos de dano, todos dentro de 24 metros estão vulneráveis.
Para dano de fragmentação, todos que estiverem dentro de (5 x dados de dano de fragmentação) metros estão vulneráveis.
Veja B414.
demolition-armor-devisor-tooltip:
Divisor
Valor para dividir o dano com base na distância em metros do centro da explosão. Veja B414.
Você pode inserir: 3 (padrão), 2 ou 1.
Padrão: Dano básico dividido por (3 x a distância em metros a partir da explosão).
Modificador de Dano, Veja B108.
Explosão +100% = Dano básico dividido por (2 x a distância em metros a partir da explosão).
Explosão +150% = Dano básico dividido por (1 x a distância em metros a partir da explosão).
demolition-target-tooltip:
Distância do alvo ao centro da explosão.
Dano básico dividido por (3 x a distância em metros a partir da explosão), arredondado para baixo.
Veja B414.
demolition-how-much-tooltip:
Determina a quantidade de explosivos com base no dano. TNT = 1.0
Veja B415.
demolition-how-big-tooltip:
Quão Grande
Determina o quão grande é a explosão com base no dano.
Veja B415.
fragmentation-skill-tooltip:
Nível de habilidade base para o ataque dos fragmentos.
Um alvo é automaticamente atingindo se o ataque explosivo atingi-lo em cheio.
Apenas três modificadores se aplicam:
- O modificador de distância do centro da explosão até o alvo.
- O modificador devido à posição do alvo (deitado, etc.).
- O Modificador de Tamanho do alvo.
É possível que mais de um fragmento atinja um mesmo alvo!
Para cada três pontos de margem de sucesso na jogada de ataque, um fragmento adicional atinge o alvo.
fragmentation-range-tooltip: Range modifier for the distance from the center of the blast to the target. B415
fragmentation-posture-tooltip: Modifier for the target's posture (prone, etc.). B415
inventory-carried-tooltip:
Carried
Check this box if the item is being carried.
This will also update the ON check state of any child inventory items.
Note: This may affect your Encumbrance Levels which may also affect Move and Dodge scores.
gravity-tooltip:
Standard gravity is based on 1G, earth normal.
If gravity is over 1G, then add your weight and encumbrance then multiply by Gravity - 1. Add this value to your encumbrance.
If gravity is less than 1G, multiply the weight of your gear by the Gravity value, this is your new encumbrance.
See B350.
total-inventory-value-tooltip: Valor monetário total de todos os itens (sendo carregado ou não).
total-inventory-weight-tooltip: Total weight of all items carried in .
grand-total-weight-tooltip: Grand total of PC's weight: , and all items carried.
spell-roll-modifier-tooltip: You can use the Roll Modifiers Toolbar or the Roll Modifiers Toolbox to modifier the effective skill.
spell-skill-level-tooltip: Nível de Habilidade com a mágica.
spell-difficulty-tooltip:
Difficulty Level.
Note: T/H stands for Technique/Hard, which is used by ritual magic spells.
Suggestion: If using T/H set the points to zero, use mod to get the correct spell level,
then place the actual spell on the Techniques table.
spell-skill-level-modifier-tooltip:
Modificador aplicado ao nível de habilidade.
Pode ser um número positivo ou negativo.
Os exemplos incluem bônus de um Talento, valor pré-definido baseado em outra perícia ou técnica, uma equipamento ou uma Qualidade.
spell-is-on-tooltip:
Insira a quantidade de mágicas Em Andamento.
para cada mágica que o operador tem Em Andamento.
Veja B238 ou M10.
Clique em um de cada vez, aguarde até que cada penalidade seja aplicada antes de clicar na próxima.
spell-concentration-tooltip:
Enter a 1 or more to mark the spell as under Concentration.
skill penalty for each spell.
See B238 or M10.
Click one at a time, wait until each penalty is applied before clicking the next one.
spell-resisted-by-tooltip: On a regular success, your spell must defeat the subject's resistance to work, a critical success automatically wins. See B241/M13 and the Rule of 16, B349.
spell-duration-tooltip: O tempo de duração do efeito da mágica.
spell-energy-cost-tooltip: A energia (PF ou PV) gasta para fazer a mágica.
spell-casting-time-tooltip: Tempo de operação para fazer a mágica.
spell-class-tooltip: Classe da mágica: Comum, Área, Toque, Projétil, Bloqueio, Informação, Resistível ou Especial.
show-spell-modifier-notes-label: Modificadores da Mágica (Marque a caixa para exibir no template de rolagem)
standard-character-sheet-tooltip: The standard character sheet will display the following tabs: General, Traits, Bio\Misc, Skills, Combat, Inventory, Grimoire, Updates, Help, and Options Icon.
chase-sheet-tooltip: A custom control sheet for managing chases scenes using the Rules from GURPS Action 2 Exploits, pages 31-39. If selected the following tabs will display: Chase, Help, and Options Icon
critical-miss-notes: Roll on the appropriate Critical Miss Table (B556).
display-modifier-in-header-tooltip: Se marcado, as opções Sem Modificador, Um Único Modificador e Modificador Estendido serão exibidas à direita do nome do personagem acima das abas de navegação.
no-modifier-prompt-tooltip: Os testes serão feitos imediatamente sem nenhum prompt.
single-modifier-prompt-tooltip:
Será pedido um bônus ou penalidade para ser adicionado ao teste.
Isso não afetará as rolagem de dano.
extended-modifier-prompt-tooltip:
Em vez de um único modificador, os testes pedem uma série de modificadores, para lembrá-lo de bônus/penalidades em potencial.
Isso não afetará as rolagem de dano.
use-skill-modifier-tool-tooltip: Exibe um campo de texto para editar os modificadores, um botão para abrir a caixa de diálogo "Modificadores de Teste" e uma caixa de seleção "NH máxima de 9".
use-melee-modifier-tool-label: Usar nos Ataques Corpo a Corpo
display-in-header-label: Exibir Opções de Testes no Cabeçalho
display-in-header-tooltip: Se marcado, as opções para Teste Públicos e Testes Privados serão exibidas à direita do nome do personagem acima das abas de navegação.
display-custom-in-header-tooltip: Se marcado, o nome do botão para Testes Personalizados será exibido à direita do nome do personagem acima das abas de navegação.
public-rolls-tooltip: Todos os jogadores poderão ver o seu nível de habilidade, testes e resultados.
private-skill-levels-tooltip:
Apenas o GM poderá ver o seu nível de habilidade, mas todos os jogadores poderão ver o resultado do teste.
NOTA: Isso agora se comporta apenas como Testes Privados.
private-rolls-tooltip: Apenas o GM poderá ver o seu nível de habilidade e o resultado do teste.
custom-rolls-tooltip:
Use esta opção para usar uma macro personalizada com o template de rolagem.

Importante: Ao inserir a macro, certifique-se de adicionar um caractere de espaço no final!

Adicione um Nome de Botão para exibir o botão no cabeçalho.

Por exemplo, a opção Testes Privados adiciona /w gm no início do teste, o que significa sussurrar para o GM.

Outro exemplo é adicionar uma opção de teste cego, onde apenas o GM vê o teste. Este exemplo usa o script da API Blind Roll, veja https://app.roll20.net/forum/permalink/5064809/.
Set Label = Blind Roll, set Macro = !broll
macro-label-tooltip:
NOTA: Para usar esta opção, você precisará de um script de API que possa interceptar os dados dos testes e enviar uma mensagem para o GM.

Para um exemplo, consulte o script de API Blind Roll, https://app.roll20.net/forum/permalink/5064809/ .
show-original-tooltip: Mostrar a tabela de técnicas original.
show-revised-tooltip: Mostrar a tabela de técnicas revisada.
point-summary-detailed-tooltip:
Visualização detalhada que exibe cada total.
Incluindo o campo obsoleto Outros.
enter-unspent-points-tooltip: Marque se você deseja controlar manualmente seus pontos Para Gastar.
public-speed-tracker-tooltip: Exibe a velocidade básica no bate-papo público.
private-speed-tracker-tooltip: Exibe a velocidade básica no bate-papo do GM.
spell-options-table:
Penalidade para cada mágica em andamento:
Penalidade para cada mágica que exige concentração:
Mostrar detalhes da mágica no template de rolagem:
abbreviation-show-rules-as-written-notes: Show Rules as Written Success/Fail notes in roll results template. Such as notes for active defenses and attacks.
update-hit-points-tooltip:
Se marcado, ao aplicar dano a um ponto de impacto, os Pontos de Vida atuais são atualizados.
Veja Ponto de Impacto e Tabela de Armadura na aba Combate > Dano.
use-malfunction-tooltip: Se marcado, o resultado do teste será usado para verificar se há mau funcionamento.
use-metric-tooltip: If checked, labels will be changed from LBS (pounds) to KG (kilograms) and encumbrance formula will use metric weights.
use-metric-distances-tooltip:
If checked, the following tools use metric.
  • Travel Time and Distances
  • Climbing
  • Digging
modifiers-to-attributes-increase-all-lab: Modificadores nos atributos também aumentam as características derivadas (incluindo PV e PF)
modifiers-to-attributes-increase-most-la: Modificadores nos atributos também aumentam a maioria das características derivadas (não inclui PV e PF)
modifiers-to-attributes-increase-none-la: Modificadores nos atributos não aumentam as características derivadas
sheet-style-description: Selecione um estilo visual para a ficha de personagem
spell-critical-success-notes-label: Notas de Sucesso Decisivo com Mágicas
spell-critical-failure-notes-label: Notas de Falha Crítica com Mágicas
show-notes-in-roll-template-label: Exibir notas no template de rolagem
editable-wound-modifier-notes-descriptio: Notas dos modificadores de ferimento com base no GURPS Campanha, 4ª Edição.
wound-notes-button-description: If you modified a note, you will not see the most recent rule updates. Press the button to get the recent rules. NOTE: this will replace any notes you made.
spell-notes-button-description: If you modified a note, you will not see the most recent rule updates. Press the button to get the recent rules. NOTE: this will replace any notes you made.
fright-check-notes-button-description: If you modified a note, you will not see the most recent rule updates. Press the button to get the recent rules. NOTE: this will replace any notes you made.
unstun-check-notes-button-description: If you modified a note, you will not see the most recent rule updates. Press the button to get the recent rules. NOTE: this will replace any notes you made.
knockdown-check-notes-button-description: If you modified a note, you will not see the most recent rule updates. Press the button to get the recent rules. NOTE: this will replace any notes you made.
unconscious-check-notes-button-descripti: If you modified a note, you will not see the most recent rule updates. Press the button to get the recent rules. NOTE: this will replace any notes you made.
death-check-notes-button-description: If you modified a note, you will not see the most recent rule updates. Press the button to get the recent rules. NOTE: this will replace any notes you made.
import-notes-tooltip: Importe notas para o campo Notas na aba Biografia.
speed-ties-description: DX has been added to Speed to help break ties. (B363)
ranged-critical-miss-by-10-description: Erro Crítico, fracasso por uma margem de 10 ou mais (não se aplica a um ataque à distância). Veja B382.
rolltemplate-warning-less-than-one-descr: WARNING: You may not attempt a success roll if your effective defense score is less than 1. (See B374)
rolltemplate-warning-less-than-three-des: AVISO: Você não pode fazer um teste de habilidade se seu NH efetivo (Alvo) for menor que 3. Veja B345.
roll-modifier-traits-tooltip: These refer to character traits that rarely change, they will not be cleared when the reset button is used.
roll-modifier-temporary-traits-tooltip: These refer to temporary traits that affect the character for a short period, such as magic spells, potions, goggles, etc. They will be cleared when the reset button is used.
rolltemplate-verify-malfunction-descript: Verify: roll 3d6 again to verify the results. (HT79)
rolltemplate-malfunction-description:
For effect, Roll 3d6 and see table on B407 or use custom table.
Note: Malfunction has "priority" over a critical miss: if both would occur, only the malfunction takes place (B382).
rolltemplate-very-reliable-description: Very Reliable: Won't malfunction unless lack of maintenance lowers Malf. (HT101, 121, 157)
default-repeating-skill-crit-success-mes: The GM may determine what happens to you. (B347)
default-repeating-skill-crit-fail-messag: The GM may determine what happens to you. (B348)
defense-encumbrance-notes: Dodge was reduced due to encumbrance.
traits-default-critical-success-notes: When you roll a critical success, the GM determines what happens to you. It is always something good! The lower the roll, the better **bonus** they give you. (B347)
traits-default-critical-failure-notes: When you roll a critical failure, the GM determines what happens to you. It is always something bad - the higher the roll, the worse the result. (B348)
reference-label-tooltip: Book abbreviation and page reference or any other appropriate reference.
language-cost-modifier-tooltip: Use this input box to modifier the number of Character Points for the selected language option.
language-talent-tooltip: If checked, you can learn languages at the next-highest level, if you spend 2 points on a langauge, instead of broken, you know the language at Accented level. This changes the available options in the drop-down and related costs. See B65.
import-tips-description:
After importing, compare your Roll20 sheet to the original application character sheet.

Roll20 doesn't support parent/child relationship, repeating tables will be imported alphabetically.
delete-repeating-tables-question-tooltip: If checked, the delete button will become active. This can be helpful if items were re-added or removed in the original application. The system is unable to delete tables and import them at the same time, so you have to delete the tables before importing.
stress-derangement-tooltip: If using GURPS Horror 141-142, Stress and Derange (Derangement) affect Fright Checks. This is auto calculated depending on the values entered into MOD and Current.
maximum-stress-tooltip: The maximum value, which is auto calculated, is based on Will. Horror 142.
current-stress-tooltip: Only enter negative values as per Horror 141-142. Additional negative values also come from failed Fright Checks.
attribute-stress-tooltip:
Stress level from GURPS Horror page 141-142.
On failed fright check, add -1 to Stress, on Critical Failure add -3!
GM could add Stress for other reasons besides failed fright checks.
Stress can be recovered by one for every ten minutes spent in mental relaxation.
GM may rule that certain indulgences can erase an extra point of Stress.
Important: If you go over the maximum stress level, apply the Stress to Derangement!
attribute-derangement-tooltip:
Derangement level represents long lasting mental harm described in GURPS Horror page 141-142.
When failing a Sanity-Blasting Fright Check, add -1 to Derangement, on Critical Failure add -3!
At the end of the day with no new stress or derangement a Will roll will erase -1 point of derangement.
+1 Will if treated by a therapist with Psychology (Clinical) or Physician (Psychiatric) at 12+.
A therapist can also roll their skill once per day to erase an additional -1 in Derangement.
Important: If you go over the maximum Derangement, the points should start going to new disadvantages!
You can keep the total in the row below.
attribute-stress-derangement-penalty-too:
The Fright Check Penalty, which is (Stress + Derangement)/2, rounded down against the player. H141
This penalty is automatically applied to the Fright Check attribute.
The penalty (modified by Fearlessness) could also affect self-control rolls, skills that demand a steady hand, and HT rolls to resist minor ailments, etc.
attribute-stress-derangement-disadvantag:
The amount of disadvantage points accrued due to derangement.
At a certain point, these points should be converted to permanent mental disadvantages!
display-modifier-summary-in-chat-label: Display Roll Modifier Summary in Chat Window
display-modifier-summary-in-chat-tooltip: If checked, the summary of all the modifiers for a roll will be display in the chat window.
chase-control-sheet-description: Use this sheet to help run chase scenes from GURPS Action 2 Exploits, please refer to pages 31-34.
chase-wipeouts-description: Wipeouts: If relevant roll fails by Stability Rating or less, but if on foot, on a regular failure, the result is a Close Call. If roll is over Stability Rating, then result is a Wreck. See GURPS Action 2 page 35.
chase-collateral-damage-description: Collateral Damage: On crowded streets, any wipeout causes an accident. If the quarry causes an accident, pursuer has -(1d6-1) to their next chase roll. See GURPS Action 2 page 35.
chase-lucky-break-description: Lucky Break: The use of luck advantages or character points to manipulate the chase to help you perform a maneuver that normally can't. See GURPS Action 2 page 41.
chase-get-results-help-tooltip:
Press this button to Get the Results of the chase.

Make sure have selected a maneuver, entered Chase Modifiers, and entered the Roll made by fields.
current-sequence-tooltip:
Use the drop-down to keep track of the current sequence, some options will update the Chase Control Sheet.

If it's the quarry's turn, the title will be turned red, same with the pursuer's turn.

Selecting Proceed to next round will start the sequence over, increment the round counter, clear some of the fields to prep for the next round.
chase-maneuver-tooltip:
Select a maneuver and use the notes box to explain the chase roll modifier you're using.

For example, you selected Stunt, in the notes you could enter, "+3 chase roll for -6 to stunt skill."
chase-modifier-tooltip: After selecting a maneuver, enter the chase modifier based on the suggestions under the Chase Rolls column.
roll-made-by-tooltip: Enter how much you missed or made your roll by, negative value means you rolled too high, positive value is a successful roll. You can have the player roll against their appropriate skill or use the skill roll button below.
chase-leader-tooltip: If it's just one person, enter that character's name. If there's a group of people, select a leader that will make the chase skill roll.
chase-mode-tooltip: A brief description of the mode of travel; land, water, air. You could enter land/water for a hovercraft.
chase-stability-rating-tooltip: Stability Rating of vehicle, if applicable. Used when checking for Wipeouts.
chase-handling-tooltip: Handling of vehicle, if applicable. This value is applied to the Chase's Final Modifier.
chase-speed-tooltip: Speed in yards per second, which is used to get a Chase Speed Modifier and applied to the Chase's Final Modifier.
chase-static-tooltip:
Check if you selected a static maneuver or you forced into a static state.
If static...
  • No speed bonus
  • If opponent is non-static they get an extra range shift, no matter who wins the contest.
  • If both of you are static, the range band doesn't change.
  • To remove static you must change your mobility (if possible) or perform a stunt.
chase-notes-tooltip: You could use the notes field to show what skill you're using for the Chase Quick Contest and additional remember notes.
chase-skill-tooltip: Enter the level of the skill chosen for the chase. You can either have the player roll their own skill applying the Final Modifier or use the provided skill button.
support-actions-tooltip: Support actions can be used to list passengers, characters in other vehicles, and then detailing actions and how it can impact the chase rolls.
chase-support-actions-notes-tooltip:
Useful for entering information of a how Chase Maneuver may affect an action.
For example, you could enter "-2 or weapon's Bulk with ranged attacks."
chase-modifiers-table-tooltip:
Use this table to track various modifiers to the Final Chase Modifier.
Examples include Higher Purpose for a +1 to chase rolls, results of a complementary skill, shock and stun penalties.
chase-support-actions-tooltip:
Typical passenger actions are Attack, Board, Seize Control, and noncombat tasks like disarming a bomb.
Boarding: Round starts at Close Range, roll contest of Acrobatics or Jumping vs opponents operatoring skill. See book for info.
Seize Control: Take control of an unmanned vehicle or seize control from a driver. See book for info.
GURPS Action 2 page 33.
object-hit-points-tooltip: GM may alter HP for unusually frail or tough objects. B483, B558.
damage-to-objects-tooltip: This tool is based on the rules starting at B483.
damage-to-objects-measure-tooltip: Enter the largest linear measurement of the object. For example, a 2x4 is 4 feet long, so enter 4.
damage-to-objects-size-modifier-tooltip: Size Modifier based on the largest linear measurement of the object. B550.
damage-to-objects-material-tooltip: The material determines the Damage Resistance. B483.
damage-to-objects-size-damage-resistance: Modify as needed, see HP and DR of structures on B558 for additional options.
damage-to-objects-injury-tolerance-toolt: Injury Tolerance of the object. B483.
damage-to-objects-health-tooltip:
Health of the object. B483.
  • HT 10, most machines
  • HT 12, homogenous objects.
damage-to-objects-health-mod-tooltip:
Enter the modifier to the base health. B483.
  • Cheap, temperamental, or poorly maintained items are -1 to -3
  • Well-made or rugged objects get +1 or +2.
damage-to-objects-base-hit-points-toolti: The calculated base hit points. B483.
damage-to-objects-weight-tooltip: The weight of the object in pounds (kg if metric), which is used to determine the base Hit Points. B483.
damage-to-objects-max-hit-points-mod-too: Modifier to the base hit points.
damage-to-objects-current-hit-points-too: Current Hit Points of the object.
damage-to-objects-major-wound-tooltip: Major Wound Threshold of the object. B483. If object suffers a major wound, roll vs HT. On a failure, one or more subsystems are disabled. B483.
team-effort-tooltip: Group effort where skilled characters cover for unskilled characters, such as climbing, hiking, and group stealth. One roll is used for the entire team. B185.
team-effort-has-skill-tooltip: The number of characters that have at least 1 CP into the skill. B185.
team-effort-highest-skill-tooltip:
Use the person with the highest skill level, they will be the leader.
They should usually lead from the front and are able to communicate with others, at least using gestures. B185
team-effort-final-skill-level-tooltip: The final skill level based on group size, number of characters that know the skill, and starting skill level.
team-effort-size-tooltip: The total number of characters participating in the team effort.
extra-effort-will-modifier-tooltip:
To perform extra effort, as described on B356-357, requires a will roll at -1 per 5% increase to an attribute.
For specific physical tasks,use the relavant skill as a Will-based roll, if that would be better. Example; Jumping (Will instead of DX).
extra-effort-fatigued-tooltip: If your character is less than one third of your Fatigue Points, then you are fatigued. Apply a penalty of your Max Fatigue - Current Fatigue as a negative penalty.
extra-effort-motivated-tooltip: +5 to Will if Motivated! Fear, anger, concern for loved one, etc. Usually requires a failed Fright Check, failed self-control roll, victim of a successful intimidation. GM decision, see B357.
extra-effort-final-modifier-tooltip:
The final modifier for the Will Roll.
For specific physical tasks,use the relavant skill as a Will-based roll, if that would be better. Example; Jumping (Will instead of DX).
Fatigue Point Cost see B357.
  • 1 FP per instantaneous action.
  • 1 FP per hour for digging.
  • 1 FP per day for hiking.
  • 1 FP per minute for lifting/moving and swimming.
  • 1 FP per 15 seconds for running.
extra-effort-attribute-tooltip:
The attribute that you're trying to improve upon.
Throwing: Can increase ST for both damage and distance, but it does NOT impact Basic Lift. You will need to make a separate extra-effort lifting roll to increase basic lift.
extra-effort-adjusted-attribute-tooltip: Adjusted Attributed based on the initial Will Modifier, +5% per -1 to Will Modifier.
macro-name-tooltip: Enter a useful name, it will displayed to you when selecting macros to apply to a skill.
custom-macro-tooltip: Enter the code for your macro.
custom-macros-tooltip: Select the custom macros that you would like to use with this skill.
hearing-tool-tooltip: Based on Hearing rules on B358 and GURPS Powers Enhanced Senses p21.
hearing-sound-tooltip: Select the cause of the sound.
shout-gas-engine-option: Noisy office, shout, gasoline engine (90 dB)
silenced-pistol-orchestra-option: Normal traffic, silenced pistol, orchastra (100 dB)
chainsaw-horn-concert-option: `Quiet` rock band, Chainsaw, car horn (110 dB)
applause-siren-option: Jet takeoff, loud hand clapping, siren (130 dB)
hearing-base-range-tooltip: The range at which you can hear the sound with no penalties. For each 'step' difference to the base range, apply +1/-1 to the hearing roll based on listener's position. B358 and GURPS Powers Enhanced Senses p21.
hearing-effects-tooltip: As described in GURPS Powers Enhanced Senses p21.
hearing-distance-tooltip:
Enter the number of yards the listener is away from the source.
  • 1 inch = 0.028 yards
  • 2 inches = 0.055 yards
  • 4.5 inches = 0.125 yards
  • 9 inches = .25 yards
  • 1.5 feet = .5 yards
  • 1 mile = 1,760 yards
hearing-tunnel-width-tooltip: Width of the tunnel or corridor in yards. If the base range of the sound exceeds the width of the tunnel, the penalty to Hearing rolls is -1 for each two steps. GURPS Powers Enhanced Senses p21.
hearing-modifier-tooltip:
The hearing modifier to apply to the sense roll. If you're actively listening, GM may allow you to use the Observation skill.

Important If there's a quick contest of Stealth vs Hearing, the modifier is in addition to the contest.
step-difference-tooltip:
The step difference is based on the listener's distance and the base range of the sound.
Example: Normal conversation has a range of 1 yard (step value of 6). The listener is at eight yards away, the sound that matches 8 yards is a Shout (step value of 9). Steps away is 6 - 9 = -3 steps away. Which is -3 to Hearing rolls.
protected-hearing-tooltip: Check if the character has Protected Hearing. +5 to appropriate health rolls.
travel-time-distances-tooltip: This tool uses the rules from Dungeon Fantasy 16 Wilderness Adventures p20-24.
travel-move-tooltip: Enter the move of the slowest person or vehicle in the group.
travel-terrain-tooltip:
Select the predominant terrain for the area being traveled upon. Use the description shown below to determine the Speed Modifier.
Mixed Terrain: If there's mixed terrain, all applicable Survival specialties work that day.
travel-terrain-modifier-tooltip: Enter the terrain modifier based on the description.
travel-weather-tooltip:
Select the predominant weather during the travel period. GURPS Dungeon Fantasy 16 Wilderness Adventures, Nasty Weather page 30.
  • Perfect: the "wind" is at the traveler's back or sails.
  • Passable: Normal/typical weather for terrain.
  • Bad: Harsh conditions, such as snow or rain in most terrains. Well lit, maintained roads may not be effected by rain, GM fiat.
  • Dire: Typhoon type condtions.
travel-base-speed-tooltip: Base speed is determined by move, terrain, and weather.
travel-mitigators-tooltip: This value is calculated using the Mitigating Circumstances tabel below.
travel-hours-per-day-tooltip:
Enter the number of hours per day spent on traveling, see GUPRS Dungeon Fantasy 16 page 23.
Muscle-Powered travel.
  • No one with Survival skill, 8 hours per day.
  • One or more persons with the Survival skill, 12 hours/day.
  • If not sleeping (lose 3 FP per day if not aided) and no one has Survival, 14 hours/day.
  • If not sleeping (lose 3 FP per day if not aided) and someone has Survival, 19 hours/day.
travel-total-miles-tooltip: Total miles traveled in the day.
travel-total-kilometers-tooltip: Total kilometers traveled in the day.
travel-mitigating-circumstances-tooltip:
Use the table below to enter in mitigating circumstances such as using the Hiking skill to improve speed. If you're actively tracking or maybe "patrolling" while traveling.
It's also useful if you want to enter a "fudge" factor based on your campaign style.
travel-mitigator-name-tooltip: Enter a memorable name for the mitigating circumstance, use the notes box to provide additional details.
travel-mitigator-percent-tooltip: Enter a percent value that will be used to modify the travel speed. NOTE: Use only number, don't add the percent sign.
climbing-tool-tooltip: Climbing tool is based on rules from B349.
climbing-tool-modifier-tooltip:
Be sure to subtract encumbrance penalties.
Make one roll to start and another every 5 minutes. Any failure results in a fall.
If you're secured to a rope, you only fall to the end of the rope, unless you rolled a critical failure.
climbing-tool-in-combat-tooltip:
Climbs in combat require a Move maneuver. B349.
For climbs inspired by rage or terror, with a cost of 1FP, doubled in an adventure or assessed by the GM.
climbing-tool-speed-tooltip: The tool assumes the distance between rungs is one foot or 0.3 meters.
climbing-tool-height-in-feet-tooltip: Enter the height in feet that the character is climbing.
climbing-tool-height-in-meters-tooltip: Enter the height in meters that the character is climbing.
climbing-tool-number-of-rolls-tooltip: The number of rolls required to climb the entered height, including the initial roll to get started.
digging-tool-tooltip: Digging tool is based on rules from B350-351.
digging-tool-basic-lift-tooltip: Enter the basic lift of the character doing the digging, (ST * ST)/5.
digging-tool-tools-tooltip: Select the type of tools being used or you can enter a custom modifier. Digging Tools B350.
digging-tool-action-tooltip: Select an action and the digging and fatigue rate will automatically update. Digging Rate = Basic Lift * quality of tools modifier * action/soil type.
digging-tool-hours-tooltip: Enter the number of hours to determine total volume and fatigue cost.
digging-tool-dimensions-tooltip:
Enter the height, width, and depth of the area to get the total volume and number of hours based on the action/soil type.
If US Units use feet, if metric, enter meters
damage-to-objects-brittle-tooltip: Check if the object is brittle, such as glass, ice, or ceramic. B136, B484.
damage-to-objects-combustible-tooltip: Check if the object is combustible, such as wood, paper, or cloth. B136, B484.
damage-to-objects-explosive-tooltip: Check if the object is explosive, such as a grenade or bomb. B136, B484.
damage-to-objects-flammable-tooltip: Check if the object is flammable, such as gasoline, oil, or gunpowder. B136, B484.
damage-to-objects-unnatural-tooltip: Check if the object is unnatural, such as a golem or undead. B136, B484.
damage-to-objects-unliving-tooltip: Machines and anything with Injury Tolerance (Unliving) such as corporeal undead.
injury-tolerance-unliving-description: Unliving are less vulnerable to impaling and piercing damage. B380. Impaling and huge piercing modifiier x1; large piercing, x1/2; piercing, x1/3; and small piercing, x1/5.
damage-to-objects-homogenous-tooltip: Things that lack vulnerable internal parts or mechanisms, such as solid or hollow objects., unpowered vehicles, trees, walls, etc. B380.
injury-tolerance-homogenous-description: Impaling and huge piercing modifiier x1/2; large piercing, x1/3; piercing, x1/5; and small piercing, x1/10, B380.
damage-to-objects-diffuse-tooltip: Swarms, air elementals, nets, etc. B380.
injury-tolerance-diffuse-description: Impaling and piercing attacks never do more than 1 HP! Other attacks can't do more than 2 HP. Exception: Area-effect, cone, and explosion cause normal damage. B380.
fragile-object-brittle-description: If limb/extremity is crippled, it breaks off! Roll vs HT, on success it is one piece, otherwise it shatters/liquefies. If HT roll to avoid death fails, object is instantly destroyed. B136.
fragile-object-combustible-description: On a Major Wound from a burning or explosive attack, roll vs HT to avoid catching fire. If the burning/explosive attack does 10 + HP of object, object is on fire. Burning objects suffer 1d6-1 burn damage per second until extinguished. B136.
fragile-object-explosive-description: On any critical failure HT roll due to a Major Wound, object explodes. If object fails HT roll vs Death, it explodes. Damage is 6dx(HP/10) crushing explosion. B136.
fragile-object-flammable-description: On any Major Wound, roll vs HT; -3 if burning/explosive attack, -3 if vitals were struck, -6 if both. On failure start burning for 1d6-1 burn damage per second. If burning, any failed Death roll will cause an explosion, 6dx(HP/10) crushing explosion. If object is Combustible, any burning or explosive attack that inflicts either a major wound or 10 + HP will automatically set object ablaze.  B136.
fragile-object-unnatural-description: Automatically fail Death roll at -HP, that much damage severs object from the force that animates it. B136.
object-badly-damaged-description: Artifact suffers halved effectiveness, at the GM's discretion. B483.
object-stressed-description: Each second object is under stress, roll vs HT. On a failure, object suffers severe malfunction and is disabled. B483.
object-destroy-check-description: At each HP level listed, roll vs HT, on a failure the object is destroyed. B483.
object-destroyed-description: At the listed HP level, object is destroyed. B483.
object-shock-description: Damage can disrupt functionality, apply usual shock damage to any use of the object, GM discretion. B483.
object-major-wound-description: When a machine with many subsystems suffers a major wound, roll vs HT. On a failure, one or more systems fail. B483.
repairs-tooltip: Repairs objects based on rules from B484 to B485.
minor-repair-description: Object must have 1 or more hit points remaining. Each successful repair attempt restores 1 HP plus margin of success.
major-repair-description: Object has zero or negative hit points. Requires spare parts at a cost 1d6 x 10% of the original price of the object. Each successful repair attempt restores 1 HP plus margin of success.
repair-equipment-tooltip: Select the quality of equipment used with the repair. B485. NOTE: Most skills require equipment.
repair-missing-equipment-tooltip: Enter the number of missing equipment. Each missing item is -1 to repair skill.
repair-haste-tooltip: Decrease the amount of time at a penalty to skill. B346.
repair-skill-tooltip: Enter the skill level for the repair. An NPC can be hired for about $20 per hour with a skill of 9 + 1d6. B485.
repair-skill-modifiers-tooltip: The final modifier total based on Object Cost, Equipment quality, Missing equipment, Damaged equipment, Extra Time, and Haste.
stealth-perception-tooltip: Stealth vs. Perception is based on rules from B222 and rule clarification from Kromm posted on Steve Jackson Games Forums.
stealth-vs-perception-stealth-skill-tool: Enter the effective skill level, factoring in appropriate modifiers.
stealth-vs-perception-perception-skill-t: Enter the effective skill level. NOTE: You can replace this with the Observation skill, B211.
stealth-vs-perception-encumbrance-toolti: Select the encumbrance level of the character.
stealth-vs-perception-vision-tooltip: This column will factor all the vision modifiers and then the tool will determine the best perception to use.
stealth-vs-perception-hearing-tooltip: This column will factor all the hearing modifiers and then the tool will determine the best perception to use.
stealth-vs-perception-move-greater-1-too: If the character's move is greater than 1, apply a -5 penalty.
stealth-vs-perception-acute-vision-toolt: Enter the character's Acute Vision modifier.
stealth-vs-perception-acute-hearing-tool: Enter the character's Acute Hearing modifier.
stealth-vs-perception-versus-discriminat: If the observer has Discriminatory smell, apply a -5 penalty.
stealth-vs-perception-concealment-vision: Enter a modifier if the target is concealed by high-tech camouflage or "stealth technology". B211.
stealth-vs-perception-concealment-hearin: Enter a modifier if the target is concealed by high-tech sound dampening or "stealth technology". B211.
stealth-vs-perception-surveillance-toolt: Enter a modifier if the observer possesses suitable surveillance devices (thermograph to spot a concealed sniper, etc.) and had a successfull skill roll to use them. B211.
stealth-vs-perception-custom-modifier-to: Enter a custom modifier that GM feels is appropriate.
stealth-vs-perception-distance-vision-to: Enter the distance in yards (meters or hexes) that the observer is from the target.
stealth-vs-perception-distance-hearing-m:
Enter the distance modifier, you can use the tool Hearing Distance.
Suggestion: If you are using the single roll button below, you can assume the sound level is equal to a succesful stealth roll.
Alternatively, perform the Stealth roll first, then use it with the Hearing Distance tool, then roll the appropriate perception.
stealth-vs-perception-distance-vision-mo: Distance modifier is determined by the Size and Speed/Range Table, B550.
stealth-vs-perception-discriminatory-hea: If the observer has Discriminatory Hearing, apply a +4 bonus. B358.
stealth-vs-perception-size-modifier-tool: Size Modifier of the character performing the stealth roll.
stealth-vs-perception-hard-of-hearing-to: If the observer is hard of hearing, apply a -4 penalty. B358.
stealth-vs-perception-darkness-modifier-: Enter the total darkness penalty, factoring in all modifiers.
stealth-vs-perception-hyperspectral-tool: If the observer has Hyperspectral vision, apply a +3 bonus. B358.
stealth-vs-perception-in-plain-sight-too: If the character performing the stealth is in plain sight, apply a +10 modifier.
stealth-vs-perception-stealth-custom-mod:
Enter the total of other modifiers.
  • -5 to hide in an area without "natural" hiding places. B222
  • +3 or more if there are many hiding places. B222.
quick-modifiers-tooltip:
Use the table below to create a set of custom modifiers that can be applied to your next roll. If the modifier is checked, it will automatically be applied to the roll, but you must remember to uncheck the quick modifier if you don't want to use it.

Note, this is a separate set of modifiers from the ones you can add to the skill.
quick-mod-description-tooltip: Enter a description for the quick modifier.
display-melee-quick-modifiers-tooltip:
Check to display the quick modifiers for melee combat. If unchecked, the table will be hidden, and modifiers will be cleared.

You can also set this on the game settings level.
display-melee-quick-modifiers-setting: Check to display the quick modifiers for melee combat. If unchecked, the table will be hidden.
display-range-quick-modifiers-tooltip:
Check to display the quick modifiers for ranged combat. If unchecked, the table will be hidden, and modifiers will be cleared.

You can also set this on the game settings level.
display-range-quick-modifiers-setting: Check to display the quick modifiers for ranged combat. If unchecked, the table will be hidden.
cold-exposure-tooltip: Exposure to cold conditions and thermal shock, see B430.
cold-exposure-temperature-tooltip: Enter the effective temperature in Fahrenheit or Celsius, accounting for "wind chill".
thermal-shock-tooltip: Did the character suffer sudden immersion into icy waters? Impurities can bring the temperature below freezing! If wearing a "dry suit", suffer normal freezing. Otherwise, roll per minute, on success lose 1 FP, only failure, lose FP equal to the margin of failure. Also, check for drowning! Thermal shock is based on rules from B430.
lower-comfort-zone-tooltip: Enter the lower temperature of the comfort zone. Humans have a comfort zone of 35 to 90°F (2 to 32°C). See Temperature Tolerance B93.
temperature-tolerance-tooltip: Enter the character's temperature tolerance, B93. Each level will decrease the lower comfort zone by HT degrees fahrenheit. If the character has a negative temperature tolerance, the lower comfort zone will increase by HT degrees fahrenheit.
temperature-tolerance-health-tooltip: Enter the character's HT that will be used with Temperature Tolerance.
cold-exposure-health-tooltip: Enter the character's HT or HT-based Survival (Arctic) skill level. B430.
cold-exposure-health-modifier-total-tool: The total modifier that will be applied to the final roll.
cold-exposure-effective-health-tooltip: The effective HT roll of the character.
temperature-modifier-tooltip: Effective temperature modifier, for every 10° below 0°F or 5° below -18°C, apply a -1 modifier.
heat-exposure-tooltip: Exposure to heat conditions, see B434.
heat-exposure-temperature-tooltip: Enter the effective temperature in Fahrenheit or Celsius, accounting for "heat index".
upper-comfort-zone-tooltip: Enter the upper temperature of the comfort zone. Humans have a comfort zone of 35 to 90°F (2 to 32°C). See Temperature Tolerance B93.
heat-exposure-lower-comfort-zone-tooltip: Note: Use the Cold Exposure tool to determine the effective lower comfort zone and enter the value here. The upper and lower comfort zones are used to determine the Intense Heat Threshold.
heat-temperature-modifier-tooltip:
Effective temperature modifier, for every 10° above upper comfort zone minus 10° or 5° above upper comfort zone minus 10°, apply a -1 modifier.
Example, normal humans comfort zone is 35 to 90°F, so the modifier would be applied for every 10° above 80°F.
heat-exposure-health-tooltip: Enter the character's HT or HT-based Survival (Desert) skill level. B434.
heat-temperature-tolerance-tooltip: Enter the character's temperature tolerance, B93. Each level will increase the upper comfort zone by HT degrees fahrenheit. If the character has a negative temperature tolerance, the upper comfort zone will decrease by HT degrees fahrenheit.
heat-exposure-health-modifier-total-tool: The total modifier that will be applied to the final roll.
heat-exposure-effective-health-tooltip: The effective HT roll of the character.
spell-parent-id-tooltip: For spells, the row id can used to link a spell to a parent spell. Tip: You could name the parent a college name or some other group name.
spell-indent-tooltip: Select the indent level of the spell. This is handy to help show the spell belongs to a parent spell.
intense-heat-threshold-tooltip:
The temperature at which the character will start to suffer from intense heat. B434.
Intense Heat is calculated as the difference between the lower comfort zone and the upper comfort zone, then multiply by 6. For humans, with tolerance of 35 to 90 °F, Intense Heat occurs at 330°F. (90 - 35) * 6 = 330. B434.
intense-heat-frequency-label: second, armor protects DR x 3 seconds.
import-tool-tooltip: Uses a standard json format to import a character. There are existing methods to export data for GCA5 and GCS.
chat-style-tooltip: Selects a visual style for the chat roll results.
breaking-bindings-tooltip: Breaking bindings tool based on rules from GURPS Low Tech 130.
binding-strength-tooltip:
Effective ST of rope based on the amount of weight it supports and the number of coils. GURPS Low-Tech 130.
Math: ST = (square root of dynamic load limit /2) plus +1 ST per extra coil. Dynamic load limit = ropes support weight / 2.
breaking-bindings-supports-tooltip: Enter the amount of weight the rope supports. For example, a 1" hemp rope can support 2,000 pounds. See Rope, String, and Thread on GURPS Low-Tech 23 for more examples.
breaking-bindings-coils-tooltip: Enter the number of coils the rope around the prisoner, about 2 yards of rope for a normal-sized human. Each coil after the first gives +1 ST to the rope.
breaking-bindings-contest-description: Prisoner must win a Quick Contest of their ST versus rope's ST. Each attempt takes a minute and costs 1 FP; repeated attempts have a cumulative -1 ST to the prisoner's ST. If prisoner loses and bindings are thin wire, prisoner suffers 1 HP of cutting damage. Critical Failure means a temporarily crippled arm. GURPS Low Tech 130.
drinking-intoxication-tooltip: Drinking and intoxication tool based on rules from GURPS Basic Set 439.
drinking-intoxication-drinks-tooltip:
Enter the number of drinks consumed. B439.
One drink is equal to a...
  • 12 oz beer
  • 5 oz glass of wine
  • 1.5 oz shot of spirits
drinking-intoxication-total-drinks-toolt: Enter the total number of drinks consumed during this session, used with the sobering up rules. B439.
drinking-intoxication-base-skill-level-t: Enter the character's base skill level for drinking and intoxication checks. Either the Health (HT) score or Carousing skill level.
drinking-intoxication-base-skill-level-m: Enter an optional modifier to the base skill level.
drinking-intoxication-has-eaten-tooltip: Check if the character has eaten a full meal within the last hour. B439.
drinking-intoxication-recently-eaten-too: Check if the character has eaten a full meal within the last 4 hours. B439.
drinking-intoxication-empty-stomach-tool: Check if the character has an empty stomach. B439.
drinking-intoxication-no-perk-tooltip: Check if the character does not have the Alcohol Tolerance perk. B439.
drinking-intoxication-alcohol-tolerance-: Enter the character's Alcohol Tolerance perk level. B439.
drinking-intoxication-alcohol-intoleranc: Check if the character has the Alcohol Intolerance disadvantage. B439.
drinking-intoxication-roll-tooltip: After every hour of drinking, roll the dice to check for drinking and intoxication results.
drinking-intoxication-stop-drinking-chec: After you stop drinking, check for hangovers and recovery.
drinking-intoxication-hangover-roll-tool: After you stop drinking, check to see if you will suffer a hangover. Use the text box to add a custom modifier.
drinking-intoxication-sober-up-roll-tool: After you stop drinking, check to see if you will sober up. Use the text box to add a custom modifier.
drinking-intoxication-strength-score-too: Enter the character's Strength (ST) score, this determines the modifier to the skill check. -1 skill per drink over ST/4. Basic 439.
large-area-injury-tooltip: Large-Area Injury Attacks that affect most of the body; dragon's breath, bomb blast, huge fire, acid pit, or attacker that has size modifier difference of 7 or higher compared to defender. If DR varies by hit location, determine effective DR using average of torso DR and the DR of least protected hit location exposed to the attack. If DR varies by damage type, use the least protected value. A location protected by cover or masked by the body does not count as exposed to the attack. For example, if you're back is turned to a cone attack by a dragon, your face is not exposed to the attack. Ignore special hit-location efects. B400.
damage-tool-method-tooltip: Select a method to help calculate weapon damage. If you select Thrust or Swing, the tool will automatically update your damage with the weapon.
die-modifier-tooltip:
Select a modifier to apply to each dice.
Examples:
  • If you know Brawling at DX+2 or higher, you can add +1 damage per die.
  • If Boxing is DX+1, add +1 per die.
  • If Boxing is DX+2 or higher, add +2 per die.
  • If Karate is DX, add +1 per die.
  • If Boxing is DX+1 or higher, add +2 per die.
  • If Weapon Master and skill is DX+1, add +1 per die.
  • If Weapon Master and skill is DX+2 or higher, add +2 per die.
  • Mighty blow or All-Out Attack (Strong). +1 per die.
  • Shove is -1 per die.
damage-modifier-tooltip: A flat modifier to the damage roll. Doesn't apply to each die. For example, Mighty Blow or All-Out Attack (Strong) add +2 damage if there's only one die.
apply-modifier-dice-plus-add-tooltip: Apply the optional rule Modify Dice + Adds. Any +4 becomes +1d6, any +7 becomes +2d6. B269
armor-on-toggle-tooltip: Toggle the layer DR on or off. This will update summary column.
vehicle-sheet-tooltip: The vehicle sheet based on rules from GURPS Basic 462-470 and Damage to Objects 483.
vehicle-notes-tooltip: Enter notes about the vehicle, such as modifiers to Health, Top Speed, and manuevering traits. A good example are vehicle options from GURPS Action 6 Tricked Out Rides.
vehicle-type-tooltip:
Enter a description for the type of vehicle.
  • Ground
  • Ground/Road
  • Ground/Rail
  • Watercraft
  • Aircraft
  • Spacecraft
  • Amphibious
  • Etc.
vehicle-tech-level-tooltip: Enter the tech level of the vehicle.
vehicle-strength-tooltip: Enter the Strength of the Vehicle. An unpowered vehicle will have a Strength of zero. B462.
vehicle-hit-points-tooltip: Enter the hit points of the vehicle. B462.
vehicle-handling-tooltip: Vehicle Handling modifies Control Rolls, B466.
vehicle-stability-rating-tooltip: Vehicle Stability Rating determines if the failed Control Roll is a minor or major failure, B466.
vehicle-health-tooltip:
Vehicle's Health. B466. Use the check-boxes to the right to identify fragile features of the vehicle. Unpowered vehicles are Homogenous with HT 12, while machines have HT 10, see Damage to Objects, B483.

Modifiers:
  • Cheap, temperamental, or poorly maintained, -1 to -3 HT.
  • Well-made or rugged, +1 or +2 HT.
  • Use the notes box for reasons why HT was modified.
vehicle-flammable-tooltip: A flammable vehicle will catch fire if it suffers 3 Hit Points of burning damage. If exposed to a flame that can't do 3 or more hit points, roll 3d6 every 10 seconds, on a 6 or less, the vehicle catches fire. Once on fire, vehicle suffers 1d6-1 burning damage per second. B433.
vehicle-combustible-tooltip: A combustible vehicle would be made of wood or paper. Make a HT roll to avoid catching fire whenever the vehicle suffers a major wound from a burning or explosive attack, on a failure the vehicle catches fire. If the damge is 10+ HP, the vehicle catches fire automatically. Once on fire, the vehicle suffers 1d6-1 bruning per second until extinguished. B136.
vehicle-explosive-tooltip: The vehicle contains explosive fuel or ammunition. If the vehicle suffers a major wound from a burning or explosive attack, make a HT roll, on critical failure, the vehicle explodes! The vehicle will also explode on any failed death roll by 3 or more. The explosion is 6d6x(HP/10) crushing explosion. B137.
vehicle-top-tooltip: Enter the top speed of the vehicle. B463.
vehicle-loaded-weight-tooltip: Enter the vehicle's loaded weight, in tons, of the vehicle. This is the maximum payload and a full load of fuel. B463.
vehicle-load-tooltip: The weight, in tons, of occupants and cargo the vehicle can carry, including the operator. B463.
vehicle-cargo-capacity-tooltip: Vehicle's cargo capacity, uses the formula of Load subtract weight of occupants, where each person is .1 tons. B463.
vehicle-curb-weight-tooltip: Vehicle's curb weight (with fuel but no other payload), which is Loaded Weight minus Load. B463.
vehicle-size-modifier-tooltip: Vehicle's size modifier, B463. Will automatically be applied to the To Hit Modifier for each Hit Location.
vehicle-crew-tooltip: Enter the number of crew members needed to operate the vehicle. B463.
vehicle-passengers-tooltip: Enter the number of passengers, non-essential crew members, the vehicle can carry. B463.
vehicle-long-term-tooltip: The letter "A" indicates the vehicle is built for long-term accommodation, with room to sleep, cook, etc. B463.
vehicle-pressure-support-tooltip: The letter "P" indicates the vehicle is built to support pressure (B77), such as a submarine or spacecraft. B463.
vehicle-sealed-tooltip: The letter "S" indicates the vehicle is sealed (B82) against the environment, such as a spacecraft or submarine. B463.
vehicle-vacuum-support-tooltip: The letter "P" indicates the vehicle has vacuum support (B96), such as a spacecraft. B463.
vehicle-damage-resistance-tooltip: Vehicle's Damage Resistance, this can be used as a reference when building hit locations. B463.
vehicle-range-tooltip: The travel distance before the vehicle runs of out fuel or provisions. B463.
vehicle-cruise-percent-tooltip: Enter a percentage to calculate the vehicle's Cruising speed, which is typically about 60 to 70 percent of the top speed. B463.
vehicle-cruising-speed-tooltip: The vehicle cruising speed, which is Top Speed times Cruise %. B463.
vehicle-endurance-tooltip: Vehicle's endurance in hours is the Range divided by Cruising speed. For situations where "Loiter" capability matters more than range. Vehicle must carry provisions in order to take advantage of endurance in excess of one day. B463.
vehicle-location-tooltip: Vehicle's hit locations, this can be used to help build the hit locations table. B463. The quantity precedes the abbreviation; e.g., "3M" for a three-masted ship.
vehicle-hit-location-abbreviations-toolt:
Hit Location Abbreviations. B463.
  • A: arm
  • C: caterpillar tracks
  • D: draft animals
  • E: exposed rider
  • G: large glass windows
  • g: small glass windows
  • H: helicopter rotors
  • L: leg
  • M: mast and rigging
  • O: open cabin
  • R: runners or skids
  • r: retractable
  • S: large superstructure or gondola
  • s: small superstructure
  • T: main turret
  • t: independent turret
  • W: wheel
  • Wi: a pair of wings
  • X: exposed weapon mount
vehicle-draft-tooltip: For a watercraft, the minimum depth of water it can safely operate in. B463.
vehicle-stall-tooltip: For an aircraft, the minimum speed, in yards/second, it must maint to take off and stay airborne. "0" means it can hover. B463.
vehicle-light-speed-tooltip: The vehicle is capable of lightspeed. B463.
vehicle-earth-gravities-tooltip: The vehicle's acceleration due to gravity, in Earth gravities, calculated using vehicle Acceleration divided by 10. B463.
vehicle-spacecraft-tooltip: The vehicle is a spacecraft. B463.
vehicle-cost-tooltip: The cost of the vehicle. B463.
vehicle-acceleration-tooltip: The vehicle's acceleration, in yards/second. B463.
vehicle-top-speed-modification-percent-t: Enter a percentage to modify the vehicle's top speed.
vehicle-location-percent-tooltip: The total modifier based on disabled hit locations.
vehicle-fatigued-tooltip: Check this box if the power souce, such as horses, has become fatigued. This will affect the Top Speed.
vehicle-calculated-top-speed-tooltip: The calculated top speed of the vehicle.
vehicle-health-roll-tooltip:
Vehicle Health Roll.
  • If suffering a Major Wound.
  • To avoid catching fire, exploding, etc.
  • When reduced to zero or less HP.
  • Being used if HP is less than zero.
  • If -1xHP or -5xHP, HT Roll to avoid being destroyed.
vehicle-hit-points-scale-tooltip: The scale of the vehicle's hit points. B470. This will update the Hit Points to the right and the hit location armor.
vehicle-current-hit-points-tooltip: The current and maximum hit points of the vehicle.
vehicle-major-wound-tooltip: Major Wound threshold of the vehicle. If the vehicle suffers a major wound, GM may call for a HT roll. On a failure, one or more systems fail. B484.
vehicle-hit-point-effects-tooltip: Effects of the vehicle's hit points.
vehicle-location-notes-tooltip: Enter notes about the vehicle's hit locations.
vehicle-sync-hp-tooltip: Check to sync the hit points with the vehicle's hit locations.
vehicle-hit-location-modifier-tooltip: To Hit modifier for the location.
vehicle-hit-location-to-hit-tooltip: The final To Hit modifier for the location, adds the Vehicle Size Modifier and the To Hit Modifier for the location.
vehicle-hit-location-defense-bonus-toolt: The Defense Bonus for the location.
vehicle-hit-location-damage-tooltip:
Enter the amount of damage this location has taken.
NOTE: If you want this column to affect the current Vehicle Hit Points,
click the checkbox for Sync HP.
vehicle-hit-location-divisor-tooltip: Hit Point Divisor. If the number is 2 or higher, that means the location can be disabled and a value will be updated in the next column. See B421.
vehicle-hit-location-disabled-tooltip:
Disabled/Crippled Threshold.
If a single attack meets or exceeds this value, the extremity or structure is disabled.
NOTE: In most cases, if disabled/crippled in one injury, the excess damage is lost.
Dismemberment: If injury is twice the threshold, then extremity is destroyed. Cutting or Explosion will sever the limb.
See B421.
vehicle-hit-location-leak-tooltip: Check if the location has a leak.
vehicle-hit-location-fire-tooltip: Check if the location is on fire.
vehicle-hit-location-reduced-tooltip: Enter the percentage of change to the top speed when the location is disabled. This will automatically update the top speed. For example, if you enter 25, the top speed will be reduced by 25%. The total percentage can't exceed 100%.
vehicle-hit-location-damage-resistance-t: Enter the Damage Resistance for this hit location. Use the Notes text box to keep track of the original DR if armor is damaged.
vehicle-hit-location-scaled-tooltip: The scaled value of the hit location's damage resistance. Will automatically update when the scale is selected.
hitlocation-hits-tooltip:
Enter individual hits here, if limb is crippled, burning, etc.
Example: -6 pi (major wound), -2 burn.
vehicle-crew-notes-tooltip: Enter notes about the vehicle's crew.
vehicle-crew-name-tooltip: Enter the name of the crew member.
vehicle-crew-role-tooltip: Enter the role of the crew member.
vehicle-crew-location-tooltip: Enter the location of the crew member.
vehicle-crew-fatigued-tooltip: Check if the crew member is fatigued.
vehicle-crew-weight-tooltip: Enter the weight of the crew member.
vehicle-crew-on-tooltip: Check if the crew member is on or in the vehicle. If checked, the crew member weight will be added to the total weight of the crew.
vehicle-crew-skill-name-tooltip: Enter the name of the skill that will be used for the roll, use a skill that is appropriate for the crew member's role on the vehicle. For example, if the person is a driver, enter Driving (automobile) as the skill name.
vehicle-crew-base-skill-level-tooltip: Enter the base skill level of the crew member.
vehicle-crew-skill-modifier-tooltip: Enter an optional long term skill modifier, this will be applied to the base skill level.
vehicle-crew-final-skill-level-tooltip: The final skill level of the crew member that will be used for the roll.
vehicle-crew-control-roll-tooltip: If checked, the skill roll is a vehicle control roll, the results will updated to reflect the roll type.
crew-member-notes-tooltip: Enter notes about the crew member.
vehicle-loadout-notes-tooltip: Enter notes about the vehicle's loadout.
